sp.l: To put of these commodities; you are
A princely merchant, and affect this kind
Of traffic, that you may not die i'th' dark,
I'll tell you a brief story, which you may
Report i'th' other world, I did affect
Ambitiously thy sister Fioretta,
Abused thy father with a false opinion
Of Leonato, for my end removed
His mistress from the cloister, and persuaded
A witty nun to take her name, and cheat
The prince, whom he suspects not yet.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Damned rascal?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: For pure love to your sister I did this.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: Why having been so impious, does thy malice
Pursue me, ignorant of all thy treasons?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Would you know that? — because I am undone
In my chief hope, the Princess whom I thought
Thus placed secure, and apt for my own visit
is gone, is vanished, and as soon I may
Find the impression of a ship at sea,
And by the hollow tract in waves o'ertake
The winged bark, distinguish where the birds,
At chase 'Ith' air, do print their active flight,
As find in what part of the envious world
Fioretta is bestowed; this sad intelligence
Surprised me like a storm, nor was it safe
To look upon the Duke, who must too late
Repent his trust, and punish it. In this conflict
Of desperate thoughts, I thus resolved to see
Ferrara, and the lady I preferred,
But find things cannot prosper, if you live?
Whose angry breath will throw down what my policy
Wrought high, and strike my head beneath the ruins.
Are you now satisfied why you must not live?

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Hear me, she's still in silence, and believed
My sister by the prince.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: When you are dead, than
You will be sure to tell no tales; now shoot —

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: In my opinion, if all this be truth,
The mischief you ha' done may be sufficient,
And he may live.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Villain wilt thou betray me?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: You have betrayed yourself, and after this
Confession, as I take it, I may be
Your ghostly father, and prescribe you a penance.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I will but physic you, your soul has caught
A vehement cold, and I have two hot pills
Will warm you at heart.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: Shall my revenge be idle?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Good prince, you are too forward, and you be
So hasty, I'm of this side; did you think,
I would be false? yet lest my aim be unlucky,
Trust your own hand to guide 'em.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Thou art honest,
Thus I salute thy heart Honorio — ha, no charge.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: 'Tis time sir to be honest, I could serve you
In some court sins, that are but flesh-colour,
A wickedness of the first die, whose brightness
Will fade, and tincture change; your murder is
Crimson in grain, I have no fancy to't.
Sir you are safe.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: I see thou hast preserved me.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I'm lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: 'Tis but a minute
Since you were found, you must be pleased to walk
Into the court, the vestal you preferred
No doubt will bid you welcome. Fate I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: False stars, I dare you now.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I shall wait on you.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: I have collected all my brain, and cannot
In any counsel of my thoughts find safety;
Honorio's death won't secure my strength,
Or prop my languishing greatness; 'tis but like
A cordial when the pangs of death hang on us,
Nay to my present state no other than
Some liberal portion of a quivering stream,
Drunk to abate the scorching of my fever,
It cools to'th' taste, and creeps like ice dissolved
Into my blood, but meeting with the flame,
It scalds my bosom, and augments the fire
That turns my heart to ashes; poor Juliana,
To what a loss hath thy first sin betrayed thee ▪
Ambition hath revenged thy breach of honour,
And death must cure ambition, for I have
No prospect left, but what invites to ruin.
I am resolved not to expect my fate,
But meet it this way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Dearest Fioretta?
Ha, what offends my Princess? there is something
That dwells like an eclipse upon thy eyes,
They shine not as they did, a discontent,
Is like a mildew fallen upon thy cheek,
'Tis pale and cold, as winter were come back
To overrun the spring.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My dearest lord,
My face is but the title to a volume
Of so much misery within, as will
Tire your amazed soul to read.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou dost
Freeze up my blood already. O call back
Part of this killing language, if thou meanest
To make me understand thee; the amazement
Doth fall so like a deluge, I am drowned,
Ere I can think my fears; how have we lived
At distance? thou shouldst walk upon this earthquake
And my ground tremble not, but with this fright
I am awake, open the volume now,
I will read every circumstance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Observe then, what first becomes my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Dost thou kneel?
That posture is for them have lost their innocence;
We must do this to heaven.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I must to you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What guilt can weigh thee down so low?
Dost weep too!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I should not love my eyes if they were silent,
They know this story will too soon o'ercharge
My feeble voice, that every tear could fall
into some character which you might read,
That so I might dispense with my sad tongue,
And leave my sorrows legible; o my lord,
I have wronged you above hope to find your mercy.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Take heed, and think once more what thou hast done
Ere thou describe such an offence, lest I
Believe a fault, will drown us both with horror;
Thou hast not broke thy vow ▪ nor given away
Thy honour, since thy faith did seal thee mine?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not in a thought.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I won't see thee kneel,
Rise, and be welcome to my arms, thou hast
Done nothing can offend me Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alas — I am not Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha! this doth confirm me, thou hast all this while
But mocked my fear, and yet this weeping is
Not counterfeit, thou art too blame my love,
Is it thy jealousy, that I am cold
In my returns to answer thy affection?
Or have I less in thy esteem of merit
Than thy hopes flattered thee? or doth the time
That dully moves, and intermit the joys
We promised when the altar had confirmed us
Sit heavy on thy thought? we will awake
From this our sullen sleep, and quit off those
Sick feathers that did droop our wings; fly to
The holy man whose charm shall perfect us,
And chain our amorous souls.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Divide us rather;
Joy is a fugitive of late, and while
You think of Hymen, you remove your wishes.
Fioretta will forbid the priest.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Canst thou forget thy love so much?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Alas my lord,
you have been all this while abused, and when
I have said enough to assure your faith, that I
Am not your Fioretta, but a virgin,
Compelled to take her name, you will I hope
Kill me yourself, and save me a despair,
That will conclude my breath else in few minutes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are not you Fioretta, but a virgin
Compelled to take her name? who durst compel thee?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The Duke of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I dissolve in wonder.
Dared Mantua use me thus? thy name?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Juliana;
My blood, (Excepting what does fill the veins
Of princes) flowing from the noblest spring
Of honour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Where was Fioretta then?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Conveyed I know not whither, ere you came
To save their lives that did betray you thus.
I was too careless of my fate, that I
Kept such a glowing secret still within me,
I had no fear to be consumed, that had
Another fire within me, whose wide flame
Had soon devoured all my considerings.
Alas my lord, you did appear so full
Of honour, virtue, and such princely love,
'Twas easy to forget on whom you smiled,
I had no thought to wish myself unhappy,
Or own another name to my undoing,
Yet now more tender of your birth and fame
Than my own life, I cast myself beneath
Your feet a bleeding sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Am I awake and hear all this?

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I see my lord,
In your enraged eye, what lightning is
prepared, 'tis welcome; since I dare not hope
To live upon your smile, I would fain die
Betime, before the shame of my dishonour
Enforce a mutiny upon myself ▪
But think my lord while I confess all this
Against myself, how free I might have been,
How happy, how near heaven, above those glories,
Had not you forced me from the blessed garden
Where I was planted, and grew fair, though not
Obliged by any solemn vow, 'twas you,
Your own hand ravished me from that sweet life,
Where without thought of more than should concern
Your welfare in my prayers, I might have sung,
And had converse with angels.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Sir, I bring sad news.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I prithee speak, I am prepared for all.

sp.speaker: Pet●.
sp.l: The Duke is dead.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My father dead?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I do not like the Princess at that posture.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have forgotten your name lady — you may rise.

div.stage: Enter Honorio, Flaviano, Claudio, and guard.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My lord I bring you news welcome as health
Or liberty, your soul will not be spacious
Enough to entertain what will with joys
And strong amazement fill it; how I swell,
With my own happiness to think I shall
Redeem your noble heart from a dishonour
Will weigh down death. You think you walk on roses
And feel not to what dragons teeth, and stings,
You were betrayed. I bring a disenchantment,
And come with happy proofs.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To tell me this is not
your sister Fioretta: but a nun
Suborned to cheat me — I know all the business,
And am resolved in my revenge. Juliana,
Sweet suffering maid, dry thy fair eyes, 'tis I
Must make thee satisfaction, I thus
By thy own name receive thee to my bosom,
But you that practised cunning, shall e'er time
Contract the age of one pale moon, behold
The country I preserved a heap of ruins.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Flaviano? sir —

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Do you know whom you embrace?
Flaviano has confessed
Himself the traitor, and the black contriver
Of all this mischief; Leonato hear me,
Or by thy father newly fallen to ashes,
I shall repent I had an honourable
Thought of thee. Flaviano; madam, witchcraft,
My rage will strangle my discourse, my soul
Is leaping forth to be revenged upon
That devil; prince keep off, his very breath
Will stifle thee, and dam thy honour to
All ages ▪ Fioretta's now in court.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Ha! in the court?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This is some new device.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: I charge thee by thy blood throw of these harpies,
And do my sister justice, whom their treason
Hath made a scorn, that minute she usurps
Her name of bride, I shall forget the altar,
And turn myself the priest, with all your blood
To make a purging sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If when we
Receive our rites, thou dost but frown, or whisper
To interrupt one ceremony, I
Will make thee hold the tapers while the priest
Performs the holy office; tell thy sister
Here I bestow, what you have made me forfeit.
Present her to the nunnery, and counsel
Thy ignoble father, when I next see Mantua
To be asleep in's coffin, and his vault
Deep, and thick ribbed with marble, my noise else
Will shake his dust; thy youth finds mercy yet,
Take the next whirlwind, and remove — our guard;
Petronio we confine him to your house.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: Thou coward prince, there's not one honest man
In all the world, our sins ascend like vapours,
And will, if justice sleep, stupefy heaven,
For thine own glory wake, if thou dispense
With this, proud man will cry down providence.

div.head: Act. v.
div.stage: Enter Volterino, Hortensio, Pandolpho (With a towel.) A table set out and stools.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Such wine as Ganymede doth skink to Jove
When he invites the gods to feast with him
On Juno's wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Pandol.
sp.l: Jove never drank so brisk a nectar as I'll draw.
But does signior Bertoldi come?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: What else? my alderman o'th' cellar.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: He is our Hilas; shall we not ha' music?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: By all means, and the mermaids.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: You shall have any thing;
But if signior Bertoldi come, I have
A boon to beg, I have a pretty plot
To make you laugh.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: As you are gentlemen, do not deny me;
I have been your up-and-down-stairs-man to draw
The best blood o'th' grape these ten years,
Troy held out not longer, I have a device
shall make you merry when he comes, if you
Will give me leave to shift, and help a jest.
He is a coward still, under the rose?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: As any lives under the sun, be confident.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: The same senseless piece of timber,
You may cut him into a bedstaff.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I'll send you wine, say I am valiant,
Let me alone with the catastrophe.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: What will he do?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I know not, he were best make us laugh,
I shall expound the matter else.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My mother remembers her service gentlemen,
I left my mistress to come to you; and how?
Shall we drink like fishes? Tolle roll lolly, etc.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Sit, sit, a health to the lady you kissed last.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let it come, I'll pledge it,
And it were the gulf of Venice.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: And who's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Faith I do not know her name, nor ever kissed any thing but her glove in my life.

sp.speaker: Volt:
sp.p: But you have told her your mind?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Not I by this wine — but that's all one,
She is a lady, well bred, and companion
To the Princess, that's enough.
Here signior — would we had some wenches here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Some bouncing bona robas, hang this dull city there's no music in't, no silken music.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: O for a wench could spit fire now, that could whizz like a rocket, and fall into a 100 blazing stars, such a fire-drake would be warm company in a close room, signior.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And it were in a cellar under the Alps, it would make Hercules melt in the back.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: But for all that, I do not like a sinner of such a fiery constitution.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: You would not venture upon the golden fleece then, which is but the moral of a maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I never heard that afore.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: So say the learned, first for the difficulty to obtain it, being watched by a dragon, and then for the rarity, there being but one in all the world.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: But one maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.p: And that some hold as doubtful as the phoenix or unicorn, such things are in history, but the man's not alive that will take his oath in what climate they are visible. Here's to the swan that broke her heart with singing last.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And to the dolphin that was in love with a fiddler's boy of Thebes, who carried him cross the seas on her back a fishing, while he sung the siege of Troy to the tune of green-sleeves, and caught a whale with an angling rod.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I'll pledge 'em both; they are very fine healths. Are these your mistress's names gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.p: Mystical, mystical.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I understand they are mystical — who's this?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Save you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.p: 'Tis the drawer.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I do not like the odour of your wine
sp.stage: He throws it in bert. face.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Was it a health? let it go round gent. I am troubled with sore eyes, and this signior has washed 'em for me, I hope I shall see to thank him.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Cry mercy signior, you are like a noble gent. I saw at Rome, you are the very same, to whom his holiness gave a pension, for killing 6 great Turks in Transilvania, whose heads were boiled, and brought home in a portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: It was but 5 sir and a Sarasens.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: You are the man?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to honour you.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I desire to be your poor admirer too,
My eyes are clear to see your worth, my name
Is Bertoldi at your service.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: To you signior, a health to Julius Caesar, Prester John,
And the grand cham of Tartaria.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: You sha'not pledge him.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Make your exceptions, I'll justify 'em.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: This cavalier drank t'ee sir.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I do remember, but I cannot pledge him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No sir, I'll pledge my friend Prester Jack,
But for Julius Caesar and the grand cham they are
Pagans, I ha' nothing to say to 'em.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here is a gentleman, he seems of quality,
Enquiring for signior Volterino and Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Admit him, and he be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You'll pardon if a stranger that has had
A long ambition to kiss your hands,
Rather entreat for his access, than lose
The happiness of your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Sir, you're most welcome.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: If you will keep us company
You must be equally engaged.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My humble service, signior Hortensio's mistress.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You honour me; would I were off again.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Excuse me signior.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You're too full of ceremony.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Sir, is there any difference between you and Julius Caesar,
You would not pledge his health?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No difference in the world.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How, no difference between you, and a Roman emperor?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Divide 'em, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: O for some trumpets.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Somebody hold my sword, give me the wine,
I'll drink it —

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: So, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: O shameful!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But I shall find a time —

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Find twenty thousand years, there's time enough.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I'll be your stickler.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I ha' not pledged the cham yet, nor I wo' not, come, I know you well enough.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Know me, for what?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: For a brave fellow, and a man may believe thee thou hast done things as well as the best on 'em, but I know not where, nor I care not, tell me of Julius Caesar: I am a gentleman, and have seen fighting afore now, here's a cavalier knows it, I scorn to be baffled by any Transylvanian turk-killer in Christendom, I; thar't a

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.p: Well said, and a sandiack.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: And a sandiack, I defy the grand cham, and mufti. all his Tartars, you're a stinking obstreperous fellow to tell me of a turd and a fart, and I honour you with all my heart. Hort. He called you mufti.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And a sandiack, that is son of whore in 2 languages.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How? in two languages? than my honour is
Concerned, have I in 30 battles 'gainst the Turk
Stood the dire shock, when the granadoes flew
Like atoms in the sun,
Have I killed 20 pashas, and a Musselman,
And took the sultan's turban prisoner,
And shall I be affronted by a thing
Less than a lancepresado?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Will nobody hold me?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Gentlemen, this heat must needs be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Let me but speak with him

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: No danger of my life, let 'em go together:
And let us mind our business.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Signior, I am your friend, and pity you
Should lose so much your honour, be advised,
I'll show a way how to repair your fame,
And without danger.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: To Volterino's mistress.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I receive it, I shall have my share, I now
Repent my curiosity to see
Their humours, and to hear what they would say
Of me —

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Let 'em alone — to Volterino's mistress.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Come, to my whore.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Your whore signior?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Does that offend you?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Not me — I ha' done you right.
I am well enough rewarded and they beat me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know not how to deserve this courtesy being a stranger
But if you want a wife noble sir, and will accept of my
Mother, you shall have her before any man in Italy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
But be sure you hit me full o'th' head.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis too much, a cut o'th' leg and please you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: No, let it be o'th' head.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You won't strike again?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Mine's but a foil.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: They measure and give back —

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O I am slain, a surgeon. Bertoldi strikes Pand.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: By this hand, I'll drink his mother's health first,
There's no danger and he were dead; a health to the lady
Florelia, I drink it for his sake.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Away, and get a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Come, to my lady mother.
A man is not born to be a coward all his life.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I can no more sir.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: You should ha' told me sir at first,
There is no remedy, 'tis to an honourable lady.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You must excuse me sir.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Throw't in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: At your request.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: You're most uncivil.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: You're a mushroom.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: So sir, you're a multitude, and in a tavern,
I did believe you sir a gentleman,
If you be, give me satisfaction nobly.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Then thus —

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Signior Bertoldi fly, his wound is dangerous,
We fear he will bleed to death before the surgeon come.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Out by the postern.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Pox, a conspiracy, I shall kill but one, I see that;
Would I were a mite in a holland cheese now.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I won't fail you sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He desires to speak with you before he die.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Is Bertoldi gone?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Hortensio, I guess you may be engaged:
Leave me to these things, there may be danger.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I know the private way.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Virtue and honour, I allow you names,
You may give matter for dispute, and noise,
But you have lost your essence, and that truth
We fondly have believed in human souls,
Is ceased to be, we are grown fantastic bodies,
Figures, and empty titles, and make haste
To our first nothing, he that will be honest,
Must quite throw off his cold decrepit nature,
And have a new creation — my poor sister,
She has heard the Duke's resolve.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: O let me die, upon thy bosom brother,
I have lived
Too long; they say the Duke resolves to marry
With Juliana, so they call her now,
Whose sorcery hath won upon his soul;
I have walked too long in dark clouds, and accuse
Too late my silence, I am quite undone,
There was some hope while he did love my name,
But that and all is banished; is't not in
The power of fancy to imagine this
A dream that hath perplexed us all this while?
If it be real, I will be revenged,
'Tis but forgetting what I am, and then
I am not concerned.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Rather forget the Duke,
And live to triumph in a love more happy.
He is not worth a tear.

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.l: How's this? my heart!

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Come, I will kiss these sorrows from thy cheek,
This garden wants no watering, preserve
This rain, it is a wealth should ransom Queens,
As thou dost love me, chide thy saucy grief,
That will undo the spring here, and enforce
My heart to weep within me equal drops
Of blood for these.

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.l: O my abused confidence,
Lauriana now I find hath but betrayed me,
Instruct me rage and jealousy.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Well said, take courage Fioretta,
Appear with thy own name and sufferings,
Thy sight will strike the proud impostors from
Their pyramids of glory.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: It were more revenge to die.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: Not so dear Fioretta, something glides
like cheerfulness o'th' sudden through my blood;
Despair not to be happy: let's consult,
And form the aptest way for all our honour.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: There's but one cloud in all our sky, were that
Removed, we were above the rage of storms:
That Claudio knows too much. I look upon
His life like a prodigious blazing comet;
He palls my blood; if I but meet him handsomely,
I'll make him fixed as the north-star. I hear
No whisper of him yet; were but he dead,
Juliana and her friend might revel here:
The Duke should have the name, but we would steer
The helm of state, and govern all. I have
Gained much upon Leonato's easy faith,
Who thinks me innocent, and that only duty
Mislead my nature and my tongue to obey
The Duke of Mantua and the prince, upon
Whose heads I have translated all my guilt,
And framed their jealousy at home my cause
Of flight for refuge hither — ha, my eyes
Take in confusion! The Duke and Claudio!
'Tis doomsday in my soul.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Can this be justified?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I dare confirm this truth with my last blood.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I dare not hear it. That I now could fling
Myself upon the winds —

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And should be happy
Were Flaviano's life put into balance
Against my own, to make it clear by his
Confession. To my shame I must acknowledge
Was the agent 'twixt 'em; he was pleased
to choose me his smock officer, a place
Poor gentlemen at court are forced to serve in,
To please luxurious greatness, younger brothers,
Who cannot live by fair and honest ways,
Must not starve sir.

sp.speaker: Leon:
sp.l: Flaviano's whore?
Where can we hope to trust our faith, when such
White brows deceive us?

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I do not like
This Claudio's business here, the Duke is troubled;
My whole frame trembles.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Madam Juliana?
My excellent white devil, you are welcome,
Where is your catamountain Flaviano?
You are no serpents spawn?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: O hear me sir, by your own goodness.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: When didst thou kneel to heaven?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I see my leprosy unveiled, that sin
Which with my loss of honour first engaged
My misery, is with a sunbeam writ
Upon my guilty forehead, but I have not
(Excepting the concealment of my shame,
Which charity might privilege) offended
Above what I confessed, and you have pardoned.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She hath a tongue would almost tempt a saint
To unbelieve divinity, she learned
Some accents from the first apostate angel
That mutined in heaven; away,
I dare not trust my frailty; where's Flaviano?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My soul doth apprehend strange shapes of horror.
Ha — 'tis the Princess Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Can you direct me madam, how I may
〈◊〉 with the noble lady Juliana?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: I can instruct you madam where to find
A miserable woman of that name.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Do not deceive me,
I came to visit her whom the Duke's love
And confluence of glories must create
A Duchess, to whose greatness I must pay
My adoration.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Do not mock her, madam,
To whose undoing nothing wants but death;
Let not my sin, which cannot hope your pardon,
Make you forget your virtue; princely natures,
As they are next to forms angelical,
Show the next acts of pity, not derision,
When we are fallen from innocence.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For the most injured Princess, Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: You must know more, I come to take revenge
And kill thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thus I kneel to meet your wounds,
And shall account the drops my proud veins weep
Spent for my cure; o madam you are not cruel,
You have too soft, too merciful a look;
When you see me, your countenance should wear
Upon it all the terrors that pale men
Can apprehend from the wild face of war,
A civil war, that wo' not spare the womb
That groaned and gave it life, this would become you,
Or fancy meager famine when she hunts
With hollow eyes, and teeth able to grind
A rock of adamant to dust, or what
Complexion the devouring pest should have,
Were it to take a shape, and when you put
Their horrors in your visage, look on me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: What hath prepared this bold resolve?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A hope
To be your sacrifice; I was not before
Without a thought to wish myself thus laid,
And at your feet to beg you would destroy me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Can you so easily consent to die,
And know not whether afterwards this guilt
Would fling thy wand'ring soul?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes. I would pray
And ask yourself, and the wronged world forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Why didst thou use me thus?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I could, if you
Durst hear me, say something perhaps would take
Your charity. Do you weep? gentle madam?
And not one crimson drop from me, to wait
Upon those precious showers? not to invite
Your patience upon the lost Juliana,
But to call back your tears into their spring,
And stay the weeping stream, I can inform you,
The Duke looks on me now with eyes of anger;
I have no interest in a thought from him,
That is not armed with hate and scorn against me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: This will undo my pity, and assure me
Thou hast all this while dissembled with my justice.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would I might as soon invest my soul
With my first purity, as clear this truth;
Or would the loss of him were all that sits
Heavy upon my heart; I cannot hope
For comfort in delays of death, and dare
Attend you to him, though it more undo me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Rise, and obey me then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I follow, madam;
My use of life is only meant to serve you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: This is the place within the wood he promised
to meet in, there is saint Felice's chapel,
That father Cyprians cell, I hope my gamester
Will think it fit, I should not walk and wait
Too long for him, these businesses of fighting
Should be dispatched as doctors do prescribe
Physical pills, not to be chewed but swallowed;
Time spent in the considering deads the appetite,
If I were not to fight now, I could pray;
These terms of honour have but little grace with 'em,
Like oysters we do open one another
Without much preface; he that fights a duel
Like a blind man that falls but cares to keep
His staff, provides with art to save his honour,
But trusts his soul to chance, 'tis an ill fashion.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: This is the gentleman by her description
That comes to fight, another champion?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do none pursue me, what a timorous hare
This guilty conscience is, I am not safe,
I had no time to think of a disguise,
And this can be no wilderness, the Duke
Would give his palace for my head.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Say so?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: O for some Pegasus to mount! A friar?
His habit will serve rarely, seeming holiness
Is a most excellent shroud to cheat the world.
Good father sanctity, I must be bold,
Or cut your throat, nay I can follow.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Thou sacrilegious villain.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I am caught already.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: My good lord Flaviano. Father
You may come back, and help to bind the gentleman
If I did understand him well, he said
The Duke has some affairs to use his head-piece;
I would not have him out o'th' way, when I
Return — to that tree — you were best be gentle.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I can but die.

div.stage: Flau. is tied to a tree.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: O yes, you may be damned
All in good time, and it is very likely.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You have preserved my life son.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: It was my happiness to be so near,
When virtue was distressed.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: You have not done sir,
As you are noble follow me, there is
Another enemy to meet, but I
Dare be your second and direct you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: What means the friar?
I'll walk and see the worst on't.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: O for a tenement under ground to hide me ▪
This wood will hardly do't, if I can lurk
Here but till night; I am furnished well with ducats;
Your melancholy mole is happy now,
He fears no officers, but walks invisible;
Would I were chamber-fellow to a worm,
The rooks have princely lives that dwell upon
The tops of trees, the owls and bats are gentlemen,
They fly and fear no warrants, every hare
Outruns the constable, only poor man
By nature slow and full of phlegm, must stay,
And stand the cursed law, I do not think
'Tis so much penance to be hanged indeed,
As to be thus in fear on't.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Sir, look this way.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh! if I had but the heart of a woman's tailor,
I might run away now.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I am robbed and bound.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Umh, are you bound? there's the less danger in you.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: For charity release me.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You are surely bound — what's that?
I hear another whispering of that side;
Now I sweat all over, I but think
If I were naked, how maids might gather dew
From every part about me — 'tis the wind
Among the leaves. I do not like the trees
Should lay their heads together of this fashion.
You are my fast friend still.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Signior Bertoldi.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Does he name me?
You and the tree shall grow together now,
I came not hither to be known; some thief,
Or sturdy rogue; I have heard of these devices
In woods before; should I unbind him now,
He'd cut my throat, or rob me for my charity.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: I am the man for your sake undertook
To kill the prince your rival.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Did you so? I'll trust you ne'er the sooner;
Well remembered, I'm glad you're not at leisure;
You that will kill your prince, will make but little
Conscience to quarter me.

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: But he is still alive.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is he so?
Why then I am the less beholding to you.
So, you shall cancel your own bonds yourself.
How now, more persecution?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Here was a duel quickly taken up,
and quaintly too, I did not think to marry
The gentleman that challenged me to fight,
I thank your device madam.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Thank the blow you gave me sir,
I love a man dares strike.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I'll please you better with my after striking.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My mother and Hortensio?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Signior Bertoldi well met, lay hands on him
And bind him fast, he has a dangerous spirit

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Who I? you may as well say I have skill in the
Black art, Volterino, gentlemen, there's my mother.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Your son is valiant madam now I hope,
As you can wish, he has killed his man; but I
Studious to gain your favour have procured?
His pardon from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Is the drawer dead?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Dead as the wine he sometimes drew.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Farewell he; will you salute my lady signior
And give us joy? yond friar married us.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Let me go, I have my pardon.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Not yet; now you shall be hanged again,
Did not you swear I should have your mother

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You shall have her yet.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: If it be so,
He shall be worth your suit, and compound fairly.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: No, I have thought of my revenge; because
I cannot have your mother, d'ye observe,
If you expect the benefit of this pardon,
You shall marry mine.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I'll marry any living soul,

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: She's something old, till the last night I see her not
These forty years, since when she's grown so ugly,
I dare not own her, and some think the reason
of her deformity to proceed from witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Alas good gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I mean she is a witch herself,
And has two cats they say,
Suck her by turns, which some call her familiars;
She has not had a tooth this thirty years;
And you must kiss her with a spung i' your mouth,
She is so full of phlegm, else she'll go near
To strangle you, and yet they say she has
A most devouring appetite to man's flesh,
You may have a devil of your own to attend you,
And when you're melancholy,
She'll make you ghosts and goblins dance before you
Bring bears and bandogs with an o'er grown ape
Playing upon the gittern.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Where is this creature? shall he not see her first?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I left her in a sive was bound for Scotland,
This morn to see some kindred, whence she was
Determined to take eggshell to Skeedam.
From thence when she has dined she promised me
To ride post hither on a distaff.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: O here she is, what think you of a husband
Mother? can you love this gentleman, he's one
Will be a great comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Pandol.
sp.l: I like the stripling well,
He will serve to watch my pits, and see that none
Of my spirits boil over.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is this your mother
Come I'll be hanged, 'tis the more handsome destiny
Unless you will take composition —

sp.speaker: Pandol.
sp.l: Let me talk with the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I am at leisure now to wait on you sir.
Unbind, and lead him to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Flaviano? you are the gentleman his highness
Gave strict command should be pursued, I shall
Be proud to wait upon you to the court.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I won't lose my passion on such bloodhounds.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: We are agreed, heigh, here's my pardon.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Yes, I am satisfied, and can thank you signior
In several shapes —

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: The drawer.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I did want a sum like this to set me up: I was
Provided 'gainst your sword, a pretty nightcap,
And almost pistol proof, I shall be rich,
I thank your bounty, and so rid the witch.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Here's none of the Duke's hand.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: It needs not madam.
I know not yet by what device you came together thus.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I'll tell you as we walk.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Pay for a pardon and not kill my man?
The Duke shall hear of this.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No news of Flaviano yet? some furies
Have sure transported him.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: A gentleman with letters sir from Mantua.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ha! admit him — leave us, the Duke himself?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That comes to offer
A pledge for young Honorio, not in thought
Guilty of that unprincely entertainment
You had at Mantua. if my son, as fame
Is busy in Ferrara, be exposed
To your displeasure, change my fate with his,
that to my shame in part consented to
The practice of a traitor Flaviano,
Who used my power to advance his own ambition
To your dishonour, and instead of my
Fioretta, whether now alive or dead
I know not, cheat your faith with Juliana,
To quit the noble safety your sword brought us,
My life is troublesome in the loss of fame,
And Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Where is Flaviano?
Duke fled like a guilty villain from my justice,
May horror overtake him; let my son
Live by some noble deeds to expiate
His father's forfeit, and disgrace; I come
Without a guard, and were it not a crime
To my eternity, could sacrifice
Myself without expecting your revenge,
Or nature to conclude my age.

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.l: Let me have justice.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Give me justice prince.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let me have justice too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Against whom sister?

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.l: Against this lady.
She hath conspired to take away my life.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: My enemy is Duke Leonato sir,
Who hath conspired to take away himself,
A treasure equal with my life.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My enemy is Juliana sir, that hath conspired
To rob herself, both of her life and honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Mant. 'tis she, my aged eyes take leave of seeing,
Expect no object after this so welcome.
My daughter Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Dearest father.

sp.speaker: Dona.
sp.l: How, Fioretta? she is then but sister
to my Honorio, life of all my joys,
My feet have wings at this glad news.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Were you the suffering lady Fioretta?
How could you live so long within the court,
And no good angel all this while acquaint me?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: This joy is too too mighty, and I shall not
Repent my exile to be thus rewarded.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Confirm my happiness again, no treason
Shall now divide us.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your hearts grow together.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have received by Claudio the particular
Of Flaviano's treason, he has guilt
Above your knowledge sir, Juliana finds it,
And is confessed his strumpet.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: I bless now my suspicion, when I was
Conveyed from Mantua, which directed me
To leave Placentia secretly, and invite
Myself a stranger to this court, where now
I meet as much joy as my soul can fancy.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have not all this while pronounced my doom,
I fear you hold intelligence with my soul,
And know what pains I feel while I am living,
You will not be so merciful to kill me.

div.stage: Enter Claudio, Volterino, Hortensio, Florelia, Bertoldi, Flaviano.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Flaviano!

sp.speaker: Hor●..
sp.l: I present you with a gentleman,
I took rifling a hermit in the wood,
As it appears in hope to scape pursuit,
Hid in a friar's habit, who dispatched
After a matrimonial betwixt
This lady and myself.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That old gentleman should be Duke of Mantua
What think you sir?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And that his daughter Fioretta.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: She is my mistress.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: She is like to prove the Duchess of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: His grace will not use me so,
I will have justice, justice gentle Duke.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Are you mad.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I'll be revenged of somebody.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Honorio your son, to meet your blessing.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: This was the life I feared to lose by her,
Whom I supposed my rival, pardon madam.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thus circled, I must faint beneath my happiness

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Forgive my passion, and receive a brother.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.l: That name doth honour us, where is Flaviano?

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: Whose witty brain must sentence me? let it
Be home and handsome, I shall else despise
And scorn your coarse inventions.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Let me obtain, since providence hath wrought
This happy change, you would not stain our joys
With any blood, let not their sins exceed our charity.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let him for ever then be banished both
Our dukedoms.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What shall become of Juliana?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: She (If your grace more fit to judge, consent)
Shall to a house of converts and strict penance,
Where Flaviano, as the price of her
Lost honour, shall pay her dowry to religion;
What doth remain of his estate, shall be
Employed towards the redeeming Christian captives.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cheerfully obey, and call it mercy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis a most pious justice.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Justice, that's my cue, justice, justice to Bertoldi
Against signior Volterino, I am cheated.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Will you be a fool upon record?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You shall have justice.

sp.speaker: Volterino,
sp.l: We appoint you, till he learn
More wit, to be his guardian, and at your
Discretion govern his estate, so leave us.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I shall with my best study manage both.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am as good as begged for a fool.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And thus we chain our hearts and provinces.
Madam I wish you joys, to Fioretta
I give myself, my sister to Honorio.
Treason is sick in her short reign, but when
Heaven sees his time, truth takes her throne again.

div.head: Epilogue, by Juliana.
div.l: Now the play's done, I will confess to you,
And wo' not doubt but you'll absolve me too.
There is a mystery, let it not go far;
For this confession is auricular:
I am sent among the nuns to fast and pray,
And suffer piteous penance, ha, ha, ha,
They could no better way please my desires,
I am no nun — but one of the Blackfriars.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
